items.title: How to only look for change at the root level?
items.body:
Hi,

(sorry if it's not the right place to post, there is no indication in the `README.md` for support)

I don't succeed to do kind of a "deepdiff" with this library, I will explain with examples.

I'm storing entities as follow:
```
{
  'user_id_a': { id: 'user_id_a', firstname: 'John'},
  'user_id_b': { id: 'user_id_b', firstname: 'Sarah'},
  'user_id_c': { id: 'user_id_c', firstname: 'Thomas'},
}
```

And I would like to compare the previous dict to another dict:
```
{
  'user_id_a': { id: 'user_id_a', firstname: 'New John'},
  'user_id_b': { id: 'user_id_b', firstname: 'Sarah'},
  'user_id_d': { id: 'user_id_d', firstname: 'Terry'},
}
```

The ideal for me would be to same some kind of answer:
```
added: user_id_d
removed: user_id_c
modified: user_id_a
unchanged: user_id_b
```

I tried
```
ddiff = DeepDiff(a, b)
ddiff = DeepDiff(a, b, view='tree')
```

But if a subproperty like `lastname` is added, DeepDiff will return it as:
```
{'dictionary_item_added': [root['user_id_X']['lastname']],
```

And for me it breaks totally the idea of my "added/removed/modified/unchanged" results because I can no longer make this assumption:
```
ADDED: dictionary_item_added
REMOVED: dictionary_item_removed
MODIFIED: values_changed || types_changed
UNCHANGED: nothing specified
```

Something ideal would let me scope the analysis of `dictionary_item_added` and `dictionary_item_removed` to the first level. Otherwise I can still look at `dictionary_item_added` and `dictionary_item_removed` results, and if the path is a nested level of "1 or more", I can consider the object is modified. But that's patchy... and I would like to avoid that because it may be more than 1 result per object. To be more precised, an object in this case could have multiple added/removed properties... so I would have to remain that this object is modified to only run my final operations once depending on "added/removed/modified/unchanged" (not a big deal, but again, patchy).

Any idea how I could do that simply with the library? Maybe there is another library that fits this?

Thank you,

PS: I hope that's clear enough, It's late here ^^

items.title: Unknown format code 'f' for object of type 'str' ... if bool with str is compared

**To Reproduce**
    
    import deepdiff
    foo = {'foobar': True}
    bar = {'foobar': 'No'}
    deepdiff.DeepDiff(foo, bar, ignore_type_in_groups=[(bool, str)], ignore_numeric_type_changes=True)

      File "C:\Users\DEVEL\venvs\global_default\lib\site-packages\deepdiff\helper.py", line 343, in number_to_string

    ValueError: Unknown format code 'f' for object of type 'str'

items.title: Regression: ignore_paths works in 4.0.7, not in 4.3.1
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
ignore_paths does not actually ignore pathes in recent versions

**To Reproduce**
This script (diff.py):
```
#!/usr/bin/env python3

from deepdiff import DeepDiff

var1=[{'cn': 'tuser', 'first_name': 'Test', 'last_name': 'User', 'name': 'Test User', 'email': 'tuser@example.com'}]
var2=[{'name': 'Test User', 'email': 'tuser@example.com'}]

diff = DeepDiff(
    var1,
    var2,
    ignore_order=True,
    exclude_paths={
        "root['cn']",
        "root['first_name']",
        "root['last_name']"
        }).to_dict()

print(diff)
```
$ pip3 install deepdiff==4.0.7
$ ./diff.py 
{}
$ pip3 uninstall deepdiff && pip3 install deepdiff==4.3.1
$ ./diff.py 
{'iterable_item_added': {'root[0]': {'name': 'Test User', 'email': 'tuser@example.com'}}, 'iterable_item_removed': {'root[0]': {'cn': 'tuser', 'first_name': 'Test', 'last_name': 'User', 'name': 'Test User', 'email': 'tuser@example.com'}}

**Expected behavior**
Version 4.3.1 should ignore paths the same way version 4.0.7 does 

**OS, DeepDiff version and Python version (please complete the following information):**
Python 3.6.9 (default, Apr 18 2020, 01:56:04) 
Ubuntu 18.04
Linux 5.3.0-51-generic #44~18.04.2-Ubuntu SMP Thu Apr 23 14:27:18 UTC 2020 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

items.title: Allow Deepsearch to return glom compatible paths
items.body:
The python package `glom` is very useful for operating on and extracting data from nested objects with a KNOWN path.
https://github.com/mahmoud/glom

`DeepSearch/grep` is incredibly useful for finding objects at UNKNOWN paths and could incredibly powerful when combined with tools like `glom`. 
For example, it would easily allow for search and replace on nested dicts #159 with [`glom.Assign`](https://glom.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#target-mutation-with-assign-and-friends).

The result returned by `DeepSearch`/`grep` is very similar to a [`glom.Path`](https://glom.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#glom.Path) object but different enough to make conversion difficult.
```python
glom.Path('a', 'b', 1, 2)
```


```python
>>> obj = ["something somewhere", {"long": "somewhere", "string": 2, 0: 0, "somewhere": "around"}]
>>> item = "somewhere"
>>> ds = obj | grep(item, verbose_level=2)
>>> pprint(ds, indent=2)
{ 'matched_paths': {"root[1]['somewhere']": 'around'},
  'matched_values': { 'root[0]': 'something somewhere',
                      "root[1]['long']": 'somewhere'}}
```

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Return a `glom.Path` object or a more agnostic but compatible result like a `list`/`tuple` of strings that represent the path to found objects in the search.

```python
{ 'matched_paths': {"root[1]['somewhere']": 'around'},
  'matched_values': { 'root[0]': 'something somewhere',
                      "root[1]['long']": 'somewhere'},
   'path_list': [1, "somewhere", "around"]}

...

# converted to glom.Path
glom.Path(*path_list_from_deepsearch)
```

Be happy to help how I can if this seems like something that's worth adding to `deepdiff`.

items.title: When will the report_repetition feature be production ready?
items.body:
**Feature Requested**
This README states that the `report_repetition` feature is experimental only and not production ready. This comment was made four years ago and I was wondering what the status is of making this production ready?
 - [README Line](https://github.com/seperman/deepdiff/blame/master/README.md#L68)
 - [Link to commit](https://github.com/seperman/deepdiff/commit/da3333f27043fb6906358b7b7136e8d09a5f8d9c)

**Ideal Solution**
It seems like this feature works well already however, I cannot use this feature with confidence in a production system when the documentation states it is not production ready. I would appreciate any update on this feature. I am hoping the documentation was just not updated and this feature is already fully supported. I am hoping to use this with `ignore_order` when diffing two nested objects/arrays.

**Alternative Solution**
As of now, I am not ignoring order since repeated values will be missed and so unordered changes are diffed. I will have to handle this case on the client side when dealing with the diff. I can also try to order the values before the diffing logic so duplicated data appears in the same index in the arrays that will be diffed. Doing the ordering before-hand is difficult however because I don't know the structure of the objects being diffed. I am hoping for a more generic approach.

Thank you for developing this great library! It works great and I appreciate any work that goes into this library and this feature.

items.title: Is there a way I can apply diffs to objects?
items.body:
Hi Sep, first thanks for making this fantastic lib. This is a question about a potential use case. Consider this example

```python
foo = None
for i in range(10000):
    foo = some_function(i)
```
I want to track the changes of `foo`, and DeepDiff can generate a diff object each time. This is all good. Beyond that, what if I also want to record the exact value of `foo` in each iteration? I could, say, do a recursive deep copy, but that would cost an **unpredicable** amount of memory(e.g. foo contains a large list). Since we already have the diffs, is it possible to apply diffs to restore an value, like

```
       diff            diff
        ↓               ↓
None ------> value_0 ------> value_1 ...
```
Theoretically, this should greatly reduce the memory cost.

items.title: DeepDiff not excluding paths when ignore_order is True
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
When attempting to do a diff between two lists of dictionaries, if ignore_order is defined as True, and exclude_paths is provided, the exclude_paths appears to not be accounted for.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Here is the following code snippet I have been using to reproduce the error:
```
from deepdiff import DeepDiff

obj1 = {'a': 1, 'b': 'randomString', 'e': "1111"}
obj2 = {'c': 1, 'd': 'randomString', 'e': 'Cool'}

obj1a = {'a': 1, 'b': 'randomString', 'e': "2222"}
```

items.title: Regression on objects list diff when using ignore_order=True
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
It sounds to me that there is a regression following 13fbd37cd3078b1722a19f901ac6cca2bde151f7 (#150), object lists deepdiffs are now producing warnings and diffs are actually not checked, *if ignore_order=True*.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior, in 4.0.8:
```
from deepdiff import DeepDiff

class Rule:
     def __init__(self, prop1=None, prop2=None):
         self.prop1 = prop1 or []
         self.prop2 = prop2 or []
     def __eq__(self, other):
         return self.__dict__ == other.__dict__

t1 = [Rule(prop1=["a"], prop2=["b"]), Rule(prop1=["c"], prop2=["d"])]
t2 = [Rule(prop1=["b"], prop2=["b"]), Rule(prop1=["c"], prop2=["d"])]

DeepDiff(t1, t2, ignore_order=True)
```

Will output
```
Can not produce a hash for root.Not counting this object.
 unhashable type: 'Rule'
Can not produce a hash for root.Not counting this object.
 unhashable type: 'Rule'
Can not produce a hash for root.Not counting this object.
 unhashable type: 'Rule'
Can not produce a hash for root.Not counting this object.
 unhashable type: 'Rule'
```

And produce:
```
{}
```
Which is false.

**Expected behavior**
The same program run on 4.0.6 is working perfectly fine, meaning no warnings, and a correct output:
```
{'iterable_item_added': {'root[0]': <__main__.Rule object at 0x7f71eda15898>}, 'iterable_item_removed': {'root[0]': <__main__.Rule object at 0x7f71eda15c50>}}
```

items.title: Decimal / float comparison
items.body:
Comparisons between floats and Decimals don't behave as expected:
```py
>>> DeepDiff([0.1], [Decimal('0.10')], ignore_numeric_type_changes=True)
{'values_changed': {'root[0]': {'new_value': Decimal('0.10'), 'old_value': 0.1}}}

>>> DeepDiff([0.1], [Decimal('0.1')], ignore_numeric_type_changes=True)
{'values_changed': {'root[0]': {'new_value': Decimal('0.1'), 'old_value': 0.1}}}
```

Comparisons only work when `significant_digits` happens to be the same as the precision of the Decimal:
```py
>>> DeepDiff([0.1], [Decimal('0.10')], ignore_numeric_type_changes=True, significant_digits=2)
{}
```

From what I can tell, string format specifiers don't work on Decimals, hence your approach in `__diff_numbers` is not correct:
```py
>>> '{:6f}'.format(Decimal('0.10'))
'0.10'
```

You could probably fix this while sticking with your string comparison scheme using something like the following only for Decimals:
```py
str(decimal_value.quantize(Decimal(10)**-significant_digits))
```

items.title: Older Pythons get incompatible versions due to undeclared dependency
items.body:
deepdiff should declare `python_requires=">=3.4"` or similar so that the packages uploaded to PyPI will be ignored by older Pythons. Otherwise, you run into issues like this:

```
~ $ python2.7 -m pip-run deepdiff                                                                                                                                                                          
DEPRECATION: Python 2.7 will reach the end of its life on January 1st, 2020. Please upgrade your Python as Python 2.7 won't be maintained after that date. A future version of pip will drop support for Python 2.7.
Collecting deepdiff
  Downloading https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/4b/bd/d37df1dfb92149f85004a31c0d34f4988437788142b44dbaa014b6491192/deepdiff-4.0.0.tar.gz (43kB)
    100% |████████████████████████████████| 51kB 309kB/s 
    Complete output from command python setup.py egg_info:
    Python 2 is not supported anymore. The last version of DeepDiff that supported Py2 was 3.3.0
    
    ----------------------------------------
Command "python setup.py egg_info" failed with error code 1 in /private/var/folders/c6/v7hnmq453xb6p2dbz1gqc6rr0000gn/T/pip-install-rwx38m/deepdiff/
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python@2/2.7.16/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/runpy.py", line 174, in _run_module_as_main
    "__main__", fname, loader, pkg_name)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python@2/2.7.16/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/runpy.py", line 72, in _run_code
    exec code in run_globals
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pip-run.py", line 4, in <module>
    __name__ == '__main__' and run()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pip_run/__init__.py", line 18, in run
    with deps.load(*deps.not_installed(pip_args)) as home:
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python@2/2.7.16/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/contextlib.py", line 17, in __enter__
    return self.gen.next()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pip_run/deps.py", line 75, in load
    _installable(args) and subprocess.check_call(cmd)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python@2/2.7.16/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/subprocess.py", line 190, in check_call
    raise CalledProcessError(retcode, cmd)
subprocess.CalledProcessError: Command '('/usr/local/opt/python@2/bin/python2.7', '-m', 'pip', 'install', '-t', '/var/folders/c6/v7hnmq453xb6p2dbz1gqc6rr0000gn/T/pip-run-Ek0QU9', 'deepdiff')' returned non-zero exit status 1
```

If instead, deepdiff were to declare its dependency, pip (9 or later) would automatically filter out versions not valid on older platforms.

Without this feature, every downstream consumer is required to maintain an (un)conditional upper bound on the deepdiff version.

Since 4.0.0 was only recently released, can I ask that you please cut a new 4.0.1 release with this declaration and pull the 4.0.0 release so that Python 2.7 consumers aren't offered it?

items.title: comparing classes with properties
items.body:
```
>>> import deepdiff
>>> class A: 
    @property 
    def a(self): 
        return 1
>>> deepdiff.DeepHash(A)
AttributeError: 'Unprocessed' object has no attribute 'encode'
```

There are two problems here:

1. We fail to hash the property A.a at contenthash.py line 234 because property object don't have a `__dict__`. This might need special treatment, or it might be reasonable to just ignore it.
2. _prep_obj returns "unprocessed", which does not prevent _hash from calling self.hasher(), raising the AttributeError. This is a "blocking" level bug I think.

items.title: object with __slots__ and __weakref__ is not compared properly
items.body:
If I compare two objects with __slots__, which have __weakref__ in their slots (like ipaddress objects), deepdiff tries to unmangle the __weakref__.  It should probably just ignore it, or at least not try to unmangle the name.

```
In [1]: import deepdiff
In [2]: from ipaddress import ip_address
In [3]: deepdiff.DeepDiff(ip_address('1.2.3.4'), ip_address('5.6.7.8'))
Out[3]: {'unprocessed': ['root: 1.2.3.4 and 5.6.7.8']}
```

items.title: cannot compare lists of Enum objects with ignore_order
items.body:
Consider the following code:
```
from enum import Enum
from deepdiff import DeepDiff

class A(Enum):
    A = 1

DeepDiff([A.A], [A.A], ignore_order=True)
```

It gives the expected output `{}` but prints the following warnings:

> Can not produce a hash for root.Not counting this object.
>  maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object
> Can not produce a hash for root.Not counting this object.
>  maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object

The inability to hash seems to be caused by unbounded recursion when traversing the Enum instance's __objclass__, which contains the enum class A, which contains the instance again.

A couple of questions:
1. Should I be concerned with this or just suppress the warnings and go about by business? If only for performance reasons it doesn't seem right to let it get to maximum recursion depth on each such comparison.
2. If something really did go wrong here and we weren't able to compare them, why isn't it reflected in the return value of DeepDiff, for example in the unprocessed field?
3. Shouldn't the loop detection take care of this?

In the meantime I have a patch which solves the issue the wrong way:
```
--- a/deepdiff/contenthash.py
+++ b/deepdiff/contenthash.py
@@ -141,6 +141,8 @@ class DeepHash(dict):
         obj_keys = set(obj.keys())
 
         for key in obj_keys:
+            if key == "__objclass__":
+                continue
             key_hash = self.__hash(key)
             item = obj[key]
             item_id = id(item)
```

items.title: Diffing two floating point numbers
items.body:
My definition "significant digits" is different from yours.

t1 = 0.0000584916556452
t2 = 0.0000584936556451

Your definition implies that the 9th significant digit above is different.

Alternative if we look at the above number in scientific notation,

t1 = 5.8491655645217175e-5
t2 = 5.8493655645217175e-5

The 5th significant digit is different. You would get about the same result if you switched the formation from 

'{:.Xf}'.format(t1)

to 

'{:.Xe}'.format(t1) (where X should be X-1)

thanks,
Brian West

items.title: DeepSearch doesn't search for inherited class attributes
items.body:
```python
class Foo(object):
    bar = 'baz'

deepdiff.DeepSearch(Foo, 'baz')
#-> {}
```

The solution to this looks pretty simple: in `DeepSearch.__search_obj()`, change [this line](https://github.com/seperman/deepdiff/blob/master/deepdiff/search.py#L134) to `obj = {getattr(attr) for attr in dir(obj)}`. `dir()` traverses the inheritence tree, finding attributes not in `__dict__`. I'm happy to make a PR if this looks good to you.

items.title: Feature: Search for types/objects
items.body:
Currently when encountering an object, `DeepSearch` examines that object's `__dict__` without testing whether the object is what's being searched for. By example:

```
>>> from deepdiff import DeepSearch
>>> from uuid import uuid4()
>>> foo = uuid4()
>>> DeepSearch({1: foo}, foo)
{}
```

This would also allow global singletons like `None` and functions to be searched for.

This seems like it'd be a fairly small change, just an `if item == obj` check at the top of `DeepSearch.__search_obj`. If you think this a good idea, I'm happy to make a PR.

items.title: Comparing based on hashes does not work with the significant_digits option

milestone.title: v3
milestone.description:
- DeepDiff Tree view
- Diff addition and subtraction

items.body:
Unfortunately I currently don't know how to best solve this.
The following options seem possible:
-) Change the hashing function to only take n significant digits into account.
-) Use comparison without hashes if the significant_digits option is present
-) Do the comparison with unchanged hashes and postprocess the result.

My current workaround is to postprocess the diff result like this:
```python
    diff = DeepDiff(a, b, significant_digits=12, ignore_order=True) 
    if "set_item_added" in diff and "set_item_removed" in diff:
        while True:
            for item in  diff["set_item_removed"]:
                if item in diff["set_item_added"]:
                    diff["set_item_removed"].remove(item)
                    diff["set_item_added"].remove(item)
                    break
            else:
                break
```

This works because the dictionary returned by diff contains strings, which are formatted having only 12 digits.

Can't properly compare dictionaries if specific key used
Recursion into dictionaries is limited to type dict
items.body:
Recursion into dictionaries is currently limited to just those objects of (or inheriting from) type dict, as per deepdiff.py line 441

`elif isinstance(t1, dict):
            self.__diff_dict(t1, t2, parent, parents_ids)`

This causes a problem for my intended use of your excellent package, because other than my top-most dictionary, all of my nested dictionaries are subclassed from collections.MutableMapping, thus **isinstance** returns False causing my dictionary-like objects to not get processed as dictionaries.

Instead of checking for type dict, may I suggest that you could instead check for collections.Mapping (the base class for mapping i.e dictionaries). E.g.

`elif isinstance(t1, collections.Mapping):
            self.__diff_dict(t1, t2, parent, parents_ids)`

That would allow recursion into any object that supports dictionary lookups.

items.title: Request: Support Lists of Dicts
items.body:
Thanks for working on this library @seperman ! A real time saver, love it!

I have a small request that I would like to make: Can it support lists of dicts as well? So something like this for example:

``` py
from deepdiff import DeepDiff

t1 = [{"a": 2}, {"b": 3}]
t2 = [{"b": 3}, {"a": 2}]

DeepDiff(t1, t2, ignore_order=True)
```

The expected output (as a user) would be:

``` py
{}
```

But the actual output is:

``` py
{'dic_item_added': ["root[0]['b']", "root[1]['a']"], 'dic_item_removed': ["root[0]['a']", "root[1]['b']"]}
```

Which makes sense looking at the source code, because `ignore_order` is supported only for unhashable iteratable items.

But supporting that flag for lists of dicts would be very useful!

Let me know if you can support something like that. I wouldn't mind opening a Pull Request to get this going.

However, [1,2,3,4] compared to [3,2,1,4,1] should be able to tell me that an extra '1' is present in the 2nd list.
